titleStmt.title: A Dialogue betwixt Cordanus and Amoret, on a Lost Heart
Distressed Pilgrim whose dark clouded eyes

sourceDesc.bibl: Ayres and Dialogues, For One, Two, and Three Voyces Henry Lawes Francis Lovelace London, 1653. L638 Folger L638, copy 1 leaves Aa1 recto to Aa2 recto, pages 1 to 3

div.head: A Dialogue betwixt Cordanus and Amoret, on a Lost Heart.

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: DIstressed Pilgrim whose dark clouded eyes
speaks thee a Martyr to Love's cruelties;
wither away?

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: What pittying voyce I hear
cals back my flying steps?

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: Prithee draw near.

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: I shall but say kind Swain what doth become
of a lost heart, e're to Elizium
it wounded walks?

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: First, it does freely fly
into the pleasures of a Lovers eye,
but once condemn'd to scorn, it fetter' lies
an ever bowing slave to tyranies.

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: I pitty its sad Fate, since its offence
was but for Love, can't tears recall it thence?

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: O no, such tears as do for pitty call,
she proudly scorns, & glories at their fall.

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: Since neither sighs nor tears, kind Shepheard tell,
will not a kisse prevaile?

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: Thou may'st as well
court Eccho with a kisse.

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: Can no Art move
a sacred violence to make her love?

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: O no, 'tis only Destiny and Fate
fashions our Wils, Either to love or hate.

sp.speaker: AmAmoret.
sp.l: Then captive heart, since that no humane spell
hath pow'r to graspe thee his farewell.

sp.speaker: CordCordanus.
sp.l: farewell.

sp.speaker: ChoChorus.
sp.l: Lost hearts like Lambs drove from their Folds by fears,
may back returne by chance, but ne'r by tears.
